executive_summary: Athletic event organizers plan and run athletic events that don't require facilities, like marathons, cycling competitions and obstacle courses. Over the five years to 2023, the industry benefited from increased corporate spending on employee wellness events, like company-hosted races. Events tailored toward sports enthusiasts and large-scale marathons increased in popularity during the period. Combined with positive conditions in the US economy that encourage spending on events, like rising consumer spending and advertising expenditure, these trends enabled the industry to expand. In 2020, the industry was negatively impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic, which caused cancelations of public gatherings, like those organized by operators. Over the five years to 2023, revenue has been rising at a CAGR of 1.3% and is expected to reach $4.3 billion, with industry revenue expected to

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The COVID-19 Pandemic Had a Substantial Effect on the Industry
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The COVID-19 pandemic forced organizers to adapt to various protocols and public pressures to enforce social-distancing measures. Although regulations varied from state to state, many events were postponed or canceled in 2020 after the coronavirus pandemic began to drastically impact the United States. A number of major events, like the NYC Triathlon and Half Marathon, Tough Mudder events and a multitude of others, were canceled or postponed at the time.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: There has been a general rise in sports participation
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Leisure activities like watching TV and playing video games have had a slightly smaller share of time to the benefit of participation in athletic events. According to the 2022 Participation Report by the Physical Activity Council, the national inactivity rate, or the percentage of people not participating in athletic activities, has fallen some from 27.2% in 2016 to 23.7% in 2021.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The range of events has expanded greatly
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The five-year period has been marked by growth in demand for events tailored toward athletic enthusiasts, as indicated by rising athletic participation rates. According to Running USA, although the number of people finishing marathons has declined in recent years, the total number of running events nationwide has risen. Half marathons in particular have experienced the largest growth during the five-year period, while 5K races have continued to dominate running events, accounting for 49.0% of all finishers in the United States.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Operators rely on a combination of corporate customers and sponsors to generate revenue
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Competitions such as the Tough Mudder obstacle course, organized by Tough Mudder Inc., require participants to be in peak physical condition and attract runners with a challenging obstacle course that encourages teamwork and a wider range of physical challenges. These events, often run by private companies with profit incentives, have been able to generate a sizeable share of revenue by charging high participation fees and encouraging corporate teams and sponsorships or endorsements.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Consumers will have slightly more money available to spend on events
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As the United States economy continues to rebound from the COVID-19 (coronavirus) pandemic but consumers face rising inflation, per capita disposable income is forecast to rise. Advertisers and sponsors typically increase funding for events if they believe that consumers are likely to spend more, which will drive revenue. Entertaining events tailored toward athletic enthusiasts will attract participants willing to spend, while also accumulating the most sponsorship money.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Higher Awareness of Health Issues is Expected to Drive Demand for Athletic Events
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As consumers become more health conscious, the number of people willing to attend athletic events is expected to rise over the next five years. The number of baby boomers reaching traditional retirement age will keep rising, providing a greater number of participants as they attempt to remain healthy and have more time to spend on athletic activities. This increased emphasis on health is also anticipated to make it easier for organizers to get approval from local governments to organize events. Many municipalities have increased investment in athletic infrastructure in attempts to improve city livability and attract more residents.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Several Issues Are Expected to Temper Revenue Growth
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Consumers are projected to increase their work hours, reducing the amount of free time that can be used for athletic events. Consequently, time spent on leisure and sports is forecast to fall over the next few years. Organizers will also contend with increased competition from athletic activities with facilities. Sports like football, basketball, soccer and tennis have a broader appeal to consumers and the use of facilities makes the atmosphere more comfortable for participants. The large fan base that these sports benefit from also attracts more advertisers and broadcasters than many of the smaller industry events. As a result, organizers will find it more beneficial to focus on more niche endorsements or corporate sponsors.

industry_definition: This industry provides event management services for sporting events without facilities, such as marathons and triathlons. Companies in this industry also offer logistical, operational and marketing services.

negative_impact_factors: low - decreasing Barriers To Entry Level

threats: Time spent on leisure and sports

key_trends: Industry operators organize athletic events, like marathons and cycling competitions, without the use of fixed facilities. Events can
Athletic events range from small local races to large marathons and obstacle courses that are followed by a vast audience.

Despite widespread cancelations of operations in 2020 as a result of COVID-19, the Athletic Event Organizers industry has grown over the five years to 2023. Greater corporate spending on employee wellness events, backed by rising corporate profit and the growing popularity of events tailored toward sports enthusiasts, helped boost demand.

Athletic event organizers industry operators are subject to a moderate level of regulatory requirements. Industry operators are required to comply with state laws regarding event health and safety as well as receive permission from local authorities to use public places for events such as marathons and walks.

The Athletic Event Organizers industry receives a low level of government assistance. Athletic event organizers typically do not receive government donations and instead rely on businesses to fund events in return for corporate advertising.

The Athletic Event Organizers industry primarily caters to cardiovascular exercise enthusiasts. Running, cycling and walking events comprise the majority of industry revenue, as they are the most easily accessible by a wide range of fitness enthusiasts.

Operators in the Athletic Event Organizers industry typically derive the majority of revenue from entry fees and admissions from both participants and spectators. Companies generate a large amount of revenue from broadcasters and other media agencies that follow the event and provide either coverage or advertising through the event.

The geographic distribution of establishments in the Athletic Event Organizers industry closely follows overall population distribution and density. Accordingly, the Southeast contains the largest number of industry establishments, followed by the Western region and Mid-Atlantic region.

The Athletic Event Organizers industry is characterized by a low level of market share concentration. The industry is highly fragmented, as running associations that organize major events tend to focus on providing services to particular cities or geographic regions.
Cost structure in the Athletic Event Organizers industry varies relatively widely. The types of events put on by organizers vary drastically by the size, cost and demand from participants.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Businesses that organize and promote events are able to sell the rights to coverage to a variety of media outlets, like TV and radio broadcasters. Media planning and buying agencies will secure advertising deals for companies that would benefit from exposure through the event.

Revenue is generated from entry fees to events and admissions of spectators in this age category. Individuals aged 35 to 44 comprise the largest market of consumers. Individuals in this age demographic are typically more health conscious due to the onset of aging, but also are still fit enough to participate. Events are often used as fitness goals.

Individuals in this age group are typically in the peak of fitness and, therefore, participate in sporting events frequently. This segment is skewed toward individuals between the ages of 25 to 34; these individuals are becoming increasingly health-conscious and are also moving away from team sports as leisure time declines with greater work responsibilities. This segment has grown slowly as a proportion of revenue, due to more sociable events such as Tough Mudder and The Color Run being developed and marketed to this demographic.

Individuals in this age category engage in less strenuous physical activity and become more active in low-impact sporting activities such as aerobic exercise. A small proportion of participants, particularly those between the ages of 55 and 64, still compete and generate industry revenue. This segment has grown marginally as the US population ages and more individuals fall under this segment. An increasing number of baby boomers are also competing in marathons as a form of fitness, bolstering demand from this demographic.

These consumers and spectators are typically involved in walking events or shorter running events, due to their age and developing fitness abilities. Over the past five years, this segment has shrunk slightly as youth participation in sports overall has declined.

products_and_services.product_description: Running events are loosely defined as any event with an emphasis on running rather than walking, which includes 5K, 10K, half-marathon and full marathon events. Running is the most popular sport that does not involve a facility and is accessible to a wide range of ages and skill levels. Casual runners compete in shorter events, such as 5K and 10K runs, while more tenured runners contend in half and full marathons. Organizers of events have also developed fun new running events like The Color Run, where participants are showered with colored power at several stations along the race.

Other sporting events organized by this industry that do not include facilities include hiking, hunting, weightlifting, fishing and skateboarding events. This segment has maintained a relatively stable and rising proportion of revenue over the past five years, as declines in demand for some events have been offset by gains in others.

This segment includes walks for breast cancer, youth cancer, certain disabilities and other nonprofit causes. These events have remained popular nationwide because of their mission to raise money for a cause and also because they are open to individuals of all ages. Families and older individuals can easily enter these events as compared with running and cycling events, which may be too difficult or strenuous.

This segment includes road racing, mountain racing and endurance events. Such events are catered more toward men, who account for 56.0% of cycling participants according the National Sporting Goods Association. Cycling events are not as popular as running events because individuals are required to own a bicycle and training is typically more difficult and expensive as a result. Although overall dollar value has increased, cycling events have shrunk as a segment of total industry revenue due to increased demand for new running and walking events.

Multi-activity events include biathlons, triathlons and other events that are made up of two or more different sporting disciplines. Multi-activity events have declined slightly as a share of revenue due to their difficult nature, which makes them less attractive than other more casual events, such as those in the running segment. This segment includes events that were most difficult to transition to 'remote' events in 2020, but have largely resumed.

tier_1_suppliers: Concert & Event Promotion in the US
Performers & Creative Artists in the US
Construction & Mining Equipment Wholesaling in the US
tier_1_buyers: Accommodation and Food Services in the US
Arts, Entertainment and Recreation in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Time Spent on Leisure and Sports
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Industry performance is correlated with the amount of time people spend on leisure and sports. When individuals spend more time on leisure and sport activities, they are more likely to participate in industry events. Sponsorship money becomes easier to obtain if companies notice a consumer trend in increasing athletic activity. Time spent on leisure and sports is expected to fall in 2023, posing a potential threat to the industry.

Because expenditure on athletic activities is a form of discretionary spending, the industry is dependent on consumer income. When incomes rise, people have more money to spend at events. Moreover, advertisers and sponsors typically increase funding for events if they believe that consumers are likely to spend more. As incomes climb, consumers are less worried about their financial position and are, therefore, expected to participate in industry events. Per capita disposable income is expected to rise in 2023.

Organizers are sensitive to advertising spending since a large portion of industry revenue is generated from media rights, broadcasting and direct advertising expenditure. When advertising expenditure declines, events receive less sponsorship money and other relevant funding, leading to lower revenue and profit. Total advertising expenditure is expected to rise in 2023, representing a potential opportunity for the industry.

Corporate profit can determine the amount of money businesses spend on industry events. Healthy profit margins enable companies to spend more on employee wellness events, such as company marathons. Moreover, with healthcare costs rising, corporations are looking to encourage employees to stay physically fit to reduce insurance costs and maintain profit margins. Corporate profit is expected to rise in 2023 as a result of continued recovery from the pandemic.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast region comprises the largest number of athletic event organizers due to its dense population and favorable weather conditions, which prevent fluctuations in demand depending on seasonality. Events centered around running, cycling and walking endure a high level of competition from team sports such as football, basketball and baseball in the region. Florida accounts for 8.3% of industry establishments, alone.

The Western region represents an estimated 20.6% of total establishments, which is slightly higher than its 17.1% share of the total population. Health consciousness is high in this region and favorable weather conditions make it an ideal location to hold many athletic meetings such as running and cycling events. Other sports with no facilities like hiking are prominent in the area. California accounts for 14.6% of establishments.

This area is home to a large number of athletic events as it contains the heavily concentrated metropolitan areas of New York, Boston and Philadelphia, with New York containing 9.7% of industry establishments, alone. Health consciousness is higher in the area and the industry experiences less competition from sports such as football. Over the past five years, the Mid-Atlantic region has grown slightly as a proportion of industry establishments.

regulations_points.regulation_description: To meet safety requirements and prevent any possible litigation, event organizers must set up safety precautions for participants and spectators. These include physical items such as barricades and designated tracks. Companies also need to arrange paramedics and other health professionals to be on-site in the event of an accident. Events like marathons and triathlons can be extremely taxing on athletes' bodies sometimes participants need medical assistance during the race.

In response to CDC guidance, various levels of regulation were implemented in the US to discourage public gathering and large events. Those regulations have varied from state to state. According to the CDC, many industry events were categorized as, "highest risk," or, "Large in-person gatherings where it is difficult for individuals to remain spaced at least 6 feet apart and attendees travel from outside the local area."

barriers_points.barrier_title: Revenue volatility and lack of industry assistance
barriers_points.barrier_description: Revenue Volatility Level: very high. Industry Assistance Level: low - steady.

barriers_points.barrier_title: Low capital requirements and technological change
barriers_points.barrier_description: Capital Intensity Level: low. Concentration Level: low. Technology Change Level: low.
Globalization Level: low - steady. The industry is based on personal contacts between promoters, corporate sponsorship managers and broadcasters.
For small events, many workers operate on a volunteer basis as the events are not lucrative enough to pay wages.

basis_points.basis_title: Fragmented industry with low market share concentration
basis_points.basis_description: The Athletic Event Organizers industry is characterized by a low level of market share concentration. The industry is highly fragmented, as running associations that organize major events tend to focus on providing services to particular cities or geographic regions.

There has been some consolidation within the industry over the past five years. Marathons have increased in popularity each year – major events like the New York City, Chicago and Boston marathons – and these associations have increased their market share to cater to increasingly large crowds.

concentration_points.concentration_description: The largest companies that provide event management solutions typically focus on providing them to major sports events that require facilities, which is outside the scope of this industry. In 2023, the largest players in the industry are expected to account for less than 5.0% of total industry revenue, each.

The industry is highly fragmented, as running associations that organize major events tend to focus on providing services to particular cities or geographic regions. There has been some consolidation within the industry over the past five years as marathons have increased in popularity.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Large events have a diversified revenue stream and a higher profit margin.
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Larger, more high-profile events such as the TCS New York Marathon are typically more profitable than smaller industry events.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: The industry is based on personal contacts between promoters, corporate sponsorship managers and broadcasters.
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: For small events, many workers have to operate on a volunteer basis, as small events aren't lucrative enough to pay wages.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Major market segments for industry operators are relatively diversified.
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The spread of market segments suggests that there are limited entry points other than those already served my incumbent operators.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Economic uncertainties and reduced visibility due to event cancellations lead to a decline in sponsorships and advertising revenues. In 2020, the COVID-19 pandemic resulted in an expected revenue drop of 46.4%, followed by an expected recovery of 83.8% in 2023 alone as industry operations resumed, significantly increasing the industry level of revenue volatility.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Stable Participation in Sports and Spending
volatility_points.volatility_description: Relatively steady demand factors such as athletic participation rates and consumer spending typically keep revenue fluctuation low. The industry's largest events generate significant publicity and participation, generating a steady stream of revenue and further reducing volatility. Singular events related to bad weather or terrorist attacks can delay or stop major events from occurring, causing some volatility.

FAQs.question: How well does your company market to consumers with limited leisure time?
FAQs.answer: Industry performance is correlated with the amount of time people spend on leisure and sports. Leisure activities such as watching television and playing video games have gained an increasing share of this time at the expense of participation in athletic events.

FAQs.question: Does seasonality affect sales for the products and services your company offers?
FAQs.answer: Demand for industry events is highest throughout the spring and fall, as favorable temperatures and conditions allow events with no set facilities. Accordingly, most industry events are held when conditions are mild.

FAQs.question: If your company benefits from population density, are you located in high traffic areas to increase your exposure?
FAQs.answer: The heavily concentrated metropolitan areas of New York, Boston and Philadelphia are home to a large number of athletic events. Locating in one of these areas can help increase exposure.

FAQs.question: Do you reduce wage costs through seasonal employment?
FAQs.answer: In 2019, wages are estimated to account for 13.9% of revenue. Wages share of revenue has declined as event organizers have relied more heavily on volunteers and contracted employees to assist with event operations, lessening the need for employing full-time staff.

FAQs.question: Does your company integrate tracking technologies to improve time tracking during athletic events?
FAQs.answer: To improve race timing, tracking technology has become adopted by event participants for the most accurate results. Race participants are typically given a tracking chip in their race packet prior to the event.

FAQs.question: Have you established a strong internet presence through social media platforms to capture a larger audience?
FAQs.answer: Internet services are becoming more important to industry operators to market events and increase participation. Event organizers have increasingly taken to social media outlets such as Facebook, Twitter and Instagram to increase event publicity and participant involvement.

FAQs.question: Are you up-to-date with legislative and regulatory changes that may allow your company to expand into new markets?
FAQs.answer: To improve race timing, tracking technology has become adopted by event participants for the most accurate results. Race participants are typically given a tracking chip in their race packet prior to the event.

FAQs.question: Does your company work with any industry associations?
FAQs.answer: There are a number of associations that provide assistance to athletes, athletic goods manufacturers and suppliers, sports commissions and fitness brands. However, these associations do not provide any direct assistance to event organizers in particular.

FAQs.question: Is your company's profit margin in step with major competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Industry profitability is expected to account for 9.1% of total revenue in 2019. The rising popularity of more profitable large-scale events in particular have primarily driven this expansion.

FAQs.question: Does your company have to purchase new equipment on an annual basis?
FAQs.answer: Depreciable assets purchased by industry organizers include equipment for ticket sales, security and broadcasting, as well as physical structures such as audience stands. However, most industry events require little capital expense, thus reducing deprecation.

FAQs.question: How quickly can new technology be adopted? Does your company keep up to date with the latest technology?
FAQs.answer: Companies need to increasingly use the internet and social media to market events and publicize activity.

FAQs.question: How hard is it to promote your company by word-of-mouth recommendations?
FAQs.answer: Companies with a high profile attract a large number of spectators and participants, which leads to higher revenue from advertisers and broadcasters.

FAQs.question: Does your company have a recognizable brand?
FAQs.answer: Local support for events is critical to building a continued base of fans, participants and media attention.

FAQs.question: How closely do you monitor trends in per capita time spent on leisure and sports?
FAQs.answer: Industry performance is correlated with the amount of time people spend on leisure and sports. When individuals spend more time on leisure and sport activities, they are more likely to participate in industry events.

FAQs.question: Do you expect major changes in demand as a result of rising disposable income levels?
FAQs.answer: A large portion of industry revenue is generated from media rights, broadcasting and direct advertising expenditure.

FAQs.question: How closely do you monitor trends in per capita disposable income? Do you offer products for consumers with a wide range of disposable income levels?
FAQs.answer: Corporate profit can determine the amount of money businesses spend on industry events. Healthy profit margins allow companies to spend more on employee wellness events, such as company marathons.
